facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2167 of 1966 filed by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2167 of 1966. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated October 12, 1965 of Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 614 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 12, 1965 of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 614 of 1962. B. Pai and D. N. Gupta, for the

facts.text: Patna High Court set aside the award dated 23rd February, 1962 made by Presiding Officer of Labour Court Ranchi and remitted the matter back.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of an order of the Patna High Court setting aside the award dated 23rd February, 1962 made by the Presiding Officer of the Labour

facts.text: Bishwanath Prasad is a workman of the appellant company.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent, Bishwanath Prasad, a workman of the appellant, made a companyplaint in writing to the officer in charge of Nirsa Police station on September 19,

facts.text: Bishwanath Prasad made a written complaint to Nirsa Police station on September 19, 1960 alleging harassment by management and breaking open lock of Kashi Nath Singh's room.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent, Bishwanath Prasad, a workman of the appellant, made a companyplaint in writing to the officer in charge of Nirsa Police station on September 19, 1960 stating inter alia that the members of his Union were being -harassed repeatedly by the Management of the companypany and that the laboratories bad reported on that day that an Assistant Manager, a Labour Welfare Officer and others had broken open the lock of the room of a worker by the name of Kashi Nath Singh and thrown away his belongings when he was actually on duty.

facts.text: Officer in charge of Nirsa Police station submitted final report on 19th November 1960 that Bishwanath Prasad's complaint was deliberately false.

anchor.surface_text: After enquiry the officer in charge Nirsa police station submitted a final report on 19th November 1960 to the effect that the companyplainant Bishwanath Prasad had deliberately brought - a false companyplaint.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Officer dismissed the complaint on 12th January 1961 based on police final report.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub- Divisional Officer of the District acting on the final report dismissed the companyplaint on 12th January 1961.

facts.text: Management served charge sheet to Bishwanath Prasad on 23rd January 1961 for misconduct in making defamatory allegations.

anchor.surface_text: The Management served the respondent Bishwanath Prasad with a charge sheet on 23rd January 1961 to show cause why disciplinary action should number be taken against him for his misconduct subversive of discipline in making serious defamatory allegations against the officers in general and to two of the officers in particular who had been put to great harassment and humiliation at the investigation by the police.

facts.text: Bishwanath Prasad admitted lodging the police complaint in his explanation to charge sheet but said it was to pacify excited workers based on complaint from Kashi Nath Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The explanation given by Bishwanath Prasad to the charge sheet was that he had made the report to the police after receiving a companyplaint from kashinath Singh, a member of his Union with numberintention to undermine the prestige of the officers companycerned and the discipline in the factory, but simply to pacify the workers who were very much excited owing to the action of the officer.

facts.text: Enquiry fixed by Management on 30th January 1961, Bishwanath Prasad failed to attend and requested open enquiry with Labour Department representatives.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that an enquiry into the matter was fixed by the Management and the respondent was asked to appear at the enquiry on 30th January, 1961 but. he failed to attend the same and sent a letter asking for an open enquiry in which representatives of the Labour Department, Dhanbad should be present.

facts.text: Management dismissed Bishwanath Prasad from service effective from 23rd January 1961 based on enquiry report.

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry officer sent in his report and The Management acting thereupon dismissed the res- pondent from service with effect from the date of sus-- pension, namely, 23rd January, 1961.

facts.text: Factory trouble on 10th January 1961 due to inter-Union rivalry, one group assaulted another.

anchor.surface_text: Quite unconnected with the above matter, there was trouble in the factory on 10th January, 1916 when one group of workers is alleged to have assaulted another group due to inter-Union rivalry.

facts.text: Company dismissed 10 workmen on 28th January 1961 for assaulting others.

anchor.surface_text: The Company dismissed 10 workmen on the ground of their assaulting two, others on 28th January, 1961.

facts.text: Government of Bihar referred industrial dispute on 28th March 1961 to Labour Court Ranchi regarding dismissal of 11 workmen including Bishwanath Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: On 28th March 1961, the Government of Bihar referred an Industrial Dispute to the Labour Court, Ranchi regarding the dismissal of the II workmen including the respondent Bishwanath Prasad.

facts.text: Labour Court awarded on 23rd February 1962 upholding all dismissals, no relief to workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court examined the merits of the matter and held that the orders of dismissal meted out by the management to all the workmen would have to be maintained and the workmen were number entitled to any relief.

facts.text: Labour Court found management's finding on guilt of 10 workmen not unwarranted or perverse, no bad faith.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal held that the finding of the Management with regard to the guilt of the 10 workmen other than Bishwanath Prasad was number in any way unwarranted or perverse and the Management was number actuated by bid faith.

facts.text: Labour Court held dismissal of Bishwanath Prasad not vitiated on grounds from Indian Iron and Steel case.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to Bishwanath Prasad the Tribunal examined the facts and circumstances relied on by the parties and held that the order of dismissal was number vitiated on any of the well-known grounds of interference as laid down Indian Iron and Steel. Co.s Case  1  1958 S.C.R. 667.

facts.text: Labour Court rejected plea of pendency of conciliation proceedings due to lack of evidence of delivery of letters.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal numbered that numberevidence had been led to sustain the plea and the Union had only placed on record, carbon companyies of two letters which were alleged to have been addressed to the Labour Officer, Dhanbad. The Tribunal was number satisfied that the letters had actually been delivered to the Labour Officer

facts.text: Bishwanath Prasad filed writ petition under Arts. 226 and 227 before Patna High Court challenging Labour Court award.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Bishwanath Prasad, filed a petition under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution before the Patna High Court challenging the award inter alia on the ground that the Labour Court had failed to appreciate that the enquiry officer had acted malafide

facts.text: Patna High Court remitted matter back to Labour Court to determine if conciliation proceedings were pending violating S.33.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court directed that the petitioner should be afforded an opportunity to place the letters earlier referred to, viz., annexures 1 and 1-1, and such other relevant evidence in this companynection as he might choose before the Labour Court

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court did not properly appreciate scope of S.33(2)(b).

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court did number properly appreciate the true scope of S. 33  2   b  of the Industrial Disputes Act and the result of the violation thereof.

facts.text: Bishwanath Prasad admitted lodging complaint on 19 Sep 1960 and did not deny it was false.

anchor.surface_text: In his explanation to the show cause numberice the respondent admitted having lodged the companyplaint before the Nirsa police on 19th September, 1960 and the harassment and-humiliation of two officers at the investigation by the police. He did number deny that the report made by him was false

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds Labour Court award, sets aside High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the order of the High ,Court remitting the matter back to the Labour Court was -not justified.

anchor.surface_text: Examining the facts and circumstances in the light of the principles formulated by this Court in the case of Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen  1  at page 685 that In case of dismissal on misconduct, the Tribunal does number, however, act as a Court of appeal and substitute its own judgment for that of the management. It will interfere  i  when there is. a want of good faith,  ii  -when there is victimisation or unfair labour practice,  iii  when the management has been guilty of a basic error or violation of a principle of natural justice, and  iv  when on the materials the finding is companypletely baseless or perverse.

concepts.interpretation: Tribunal interferes with management's dismissal only on four grounds: lack of good faith, victimisation/unfair practice, violation of natural justice/basic error, perverse/baseless finding; applies even post s.33 violation

issues.text: Whether the order of dismissal was passed in contravention of Section 33(2)(b) of the Industrial Disputes Act?

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court one of the main pleas taken on behalf of the respondent was that the order of dismissal against him having been passed in contravention of S. 33 of the Act was invalid and ineffective and on that ground alone he should have been reinstated.

issues.text: What is the true scope of Section 33(2)(b) of the Industrial Disputes Act and the result of the violation thereof in a Section 10 reference?

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court did not properly appreciate the true scope of S. 33 (2) (b) of the Industrial Disputes Act and the result of the violation thereof.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal/Labour Court must interfere with the management's order of dismissal for misconduct applying the principles from Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen?

anchor.surface_text: Examining the facts and circumstances in the light of the principles formulated by this Court in the case of Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen at page 685 that In case of dismissal on misconduct, the Tribunal does not, however, act as a Court of appeal...

issues.text: Whether the enquiry officer acted mala fide and in violation of the principles of natural justice?

anchor.surface_text: the enquiry officer had acted malafide and in violation of the principles of natural justice in holding the enquiry. A complaint was also made

issues.text: In a Section 10 reference involving alleged contravention of Section 33, whether the domestic enquiry is of no avail and the tribunal must examine merits de novo?

anchor.surface_text: reference under S. 10 or by reason of a complaint under S. 33A of the Act, the enquiry held by the employer before passing the order of dismissal

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court one of the main pleas taken on behalf of the respondent was that the order of dismissal against him having been passed in contravention of S. 33 of the Act was invalid and ineffective and on that ground alone he should have been reinstated.

arguments.court_reasoning: Violation of S.33(2)(b) does not automatically invalidate dismissal; tribunal must still examine merits under Indian Iron principles

arguments.claim: In cases of S.33 contravention under S.10 or S.33A adjudication, domestic enquiry held by employer is of no avail

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended that in cases where in order of dismissal passed in contravention of S. 33 of the Act was the subject matter of adjudication either by virtue of a reference under S. 10 (1) or by reason of a complaint under S. 33A of the Act, the enquiry held by the employer before passing the order of dismissal was of no avail.

anchor.surface_text: The Management filed a counter affidavit justifying its action against the workmen and submitting that the award had been correctly made.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: merited dismissal. The Labour Court had the evidence before it the lodging of the companyplaint was number disputed, that the allegations therein wer

arguments.court_reasoning: Labour Court correctly applied law; HC erred

arguments.claim: All contentions depend on basic fact of S.33 contravention; if contravened, departmental enquiry no avail, whole question open

anchor.surface_text: According to the High Court all the contentions raised on behalf of the petitioner are found on the basic fact that there was contravention of S. 33. Referring to the judgment of this Court in The Punjab National Bank Ltd., Its Workmen the High Court took the view that it was necessary for the Labour Court to first go into the question whether or not there was a conciliation proceeding pending... the departmental enquiry would not avail the employer and the whole question would be open.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ers companytention , that the order of dismissal companytravened S. 33  2   b , the departmental enquiry would number avail the employer and the whole

arguments.court_reasoning: Misapprehended scope of S.33(2)(b); violation requires merits review under Indian Iron, not de novo ignoring enquiry

The Tribunal was not satisfied that the letters had actually been delivered to the Labour Officer

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n all the evidence adduced before it. Being of the view that in the absence of any determination of the basic question whether or number there was a c

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence; even if pending, no difference to merits

arguments.claim: Dismissal orders not vitiated under Indian Iron principles (no want of good faith, victimisation, natural justice violation, or perverse finding)

anchor.surface_text: Examining the facts and circumstances in the light of the principles formulated by this Court in the case of Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen 1 at page 685 that In case of dismissal on misconduct, the Tribunal does not, however, act as a Court of appeal... the Tribunal held that the finding of the Management with regard to the guilt of the 10 workmen other than Bishwanath Prasad was not in any way unwarranted or perverse... With regard to Bishwanath Prasad the Tribunal examined the facts and circumstances relied on by the parties and held that the order of dismissal was not vitiated on any of the well-known grounds of interference as laid down Indian Iron and Steel. Co.s Case

court_response_anchor.surface_text: took the view that the respondents action in defaming two of the officers of the companypany companyld number but be pronounced as an act subversive o

arguments.claim: High Court did not properly appreciate true scope of S.33(2)(b) and result of violation

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court did not properly appreciate the true scope of S. 33 (2) (b) of the Industrial Disputes Act and the result of the violation thereof.

arguments.claim: Violation of S.33 does not automatically require reinstatement; tribunal must examine merits under Indian Iron principles even in S.10 reference

anchor.surface_text: These sections do not lend themselves to the construction that as soon as the Labour. Court, Tribunal etc. finds that there has been a violation of S. 33 it should award reinstatement. It must go through the proceedings which would have to be taken under S. 10 and it would be the duty of the Labour Court etc. to examine the merits of the case in the light of the principles formulated in the Indian Iron and Steel Co.s case.

arguments.claim: Pendency of conciliation before labour officer does not attract S.33A; even if S.33(2)(b) violated, merits examined under Indian Iron

anchor.surface_text: it would be the duty of the Labour Court etc. to examine the merits of the case in the light of the principles formulated in the Indian Iron and Steel Co.s case. It has not been alleged in this case that any conciliation proceedings were pending before a Labour Court... Assuming for a moment that there was a conciliation proceeding before a labour officer, S. 33-A would not be attracted.

arguments.claim: Permission under S.33 merely removes ban; validity challengeable via industrial dispute; S.33A for direct complaint

anchor.surface_text: In The Punjab National Bank Ltd.s case 2 referred to by the High Court... even if the requisite permission is granted to the employer under S. 33 that would not be the end of the matter... The contention on behalf of the workmen that disregard of a ban imposed by S. 33 of the Act would render the employers action of dismissal void and inoperative was rejected by this Court.

arguments.claim: In S.10 reference involving S.33 contravention, tribunal decides contravention but also examines merits and justifies dismissal

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that if under a complaint filed under S. 33A a tribunal has to deal not only with the question of contravention but also with the merits of the order of dismissal, the position cannot be any different when a reference is made to the tribunal like the present under S. 10... The tribunal would have also to consider whether the impugned orders of dismissal are otherwise justified...

arguments.claim: Even if conciliation pending, tribunal must consider if employer's action justified under Indian Iron

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in our view rightly refused to go into the question of the pendency of any conciliation proceeding but, even if there was any such proceeding, it would make no difference to the result in this case. The Tribunal would still have to consider whether the employers action was justified in the light of the decision in the Indian Iron Steel Co.s case.

arguments.claim: Labour Court correctly found no justification for complaint to police; action subversive of discipline meriting dismissal

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal came to the conclusion that there was no justification for the respondents complaint to the police that the companys officials were in the habit of acting high-handedly and oppressively as alleged by him and further took the view that the respondents action in defaming two of the officers of the company could not but be pronounced as an act subversive of discipline...

arguments.claim: Employer can justify dismissal on merits even if S.33 contravened (citing Rohtas Industries)

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed on a judgment of this Court in Rohtas Industries Ltd. v. Its Workmen and the observation therein that It is well settled that if an application is made by an employee under s. 33A and it is, shown that the impugned dismissal of the employee has contravened s. 33, it is open to the employer to justify the dismissal on the merits...

arguments.claim: None of Indian Iron grounds substantiated; dismissal proper

anchor.surface_text: Not one of the grounds formulated in the Indian Iron and Steel Co.s case which could lead the Tribunal to hold that the dismissal was improper was substantiated.

arguments.claim: Orders of dismissal illegal due to pendency of conciliation proceedings

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal also examined the plea put forward on behalf of the workers that the orders of dismissal should be held to be illegal inasmuch as they were all passed during the pendency of a conciliation proceeding.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sal meted out by the management to all the workmen would have to be maintained and the workmen were number entitled to any relief. Examining the facts

holdings.text: The High Court did not properly appreciate the true scope of S. 33(2)(b) of the Industrial Disputes Act and the result of the violation thereof.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court did not properly appreciate the true scope of S. 33 (2) (b) of the Industrial Disputes Act and the result of the violation thereof. It is undisputed that the order of dismissal of the respondent was made after an enquiry on the basis of a charge sheet submitted to him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court required Labour Court to first determine S.33 contravention and ignore domestic enquiry if found, but court holds merits must always be examined under Indian Iron principles regardless.

holdings.text: Violation of S.33 does not automatically entitle the workman to reinstatement; the tribunal must examine the merits of the dismissal in the light of Indian Iron and Steel principles even in a S.10 reference.

anchor.surface_text: These sections do not lend themselves to the construction that as soon as the Labour. Court, Tribunal etc. finds that there has been a violation of S. 33 it should award reinstatement. It must go through the proceedings which would have to be taken under S. 10 and it would be the duty of the Labour Court etc. to examine the merits of the case in the light of the principles formulated in the Indian Iron and Steel Co.s case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory construction of ss.33, 33A, 10; distinguishes direct effect of violation; mandates merits review per settled precedent; harmonious reading with S.33A adjudication.

holdings.text: In adjudication of S.33 contravention under S.10 reference, the domestic enquiry is not of no avail; tribunal considers it unless vitiated on Indian Iron grounds.

anchor.surface_text: it would be the duty of the Labour Court etc. to examine the merits of the case in the light of the principles formulated in the Indian Iron and Steel Co.s case. It has not been alleged in this case that any conciliation proceedings were pending before a Labour Court...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects contention by analogy to S.33A; follows Punjab National Bank that S.10 enquiry includes merits beyond contravention; domestic findings relevant unless perverse etc.

holdings.text: Pendency of conciliation before a Labour Officer does not attract S.33A; even if S.33(2)(b) violated, employer can justify on merits.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming for a moment that there was a conciliation proceeding before a labour officer, S. 33-A would not be attracted. In any event it would be open to the complaining workman to take exception to the conduct of the management in ignoring the provisions of S. 33(2)(b).

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.33A applies only to specified authorities; violation still allows merits justification per Rohtas Industries and Indian Iron.

holdings.text: The Labour Court correctly held that the dismissal orders were not vitiated on any grounds under Indian Iron and Steel principles (no want of good faith, victimisation, natural justice violation, or perverse finding).

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in our view rightly refused to go into the question of the pendency of any conciliation proceeding but, even if there was any such proceeding, it would make no difference to the result in this case. The Tribunal would still have to consider whether the employers action was justified in the light of the decision in the Indian Iron Steel Co.s case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies four-ground test to facts; Labour Court findings on misconduct, enquiry, no mala fides upheld as reasonable.

holdings.text: Bishwanath Prasad's lodging of false police complaint defaming company officers was subversive of discipline meriting dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal came to the conclusion that there was no justification for the respondents complaint to the police that the companys officials were in the habit of acting high-handedly and oppressively as alleged by him and further took the view that the respondents action in defaming two of the officers of the company could not but be pronounced as an act subversive of discipline...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admission of complaint; police found false; no denial; humiliation caused; applies misconduct standard.

holdings.text: None of the Indian Iron grounds were substantiated; Labour Court's award upholding dismissal is correct.

anchor.surface_text: Not one of the grounds formulated in the Indian Iron and Steel Co.s case which could lead the Tribunal to hold that the dismissal was improper was substantiated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit check against four grounds; no evidence of mala fides, victimisation, etc.

holdings.text: The High Court order remitting the matter back to the Labour Court was not justified.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the order of the High Court remitting the matter back to the Labour Court was not justified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: correct application by Labour Court; erroneous scope by HC; merits justify dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court did not properly appreciate the true scope of S. 33 (2) (b) of the Industrial Disputes Act and the result of the violation thereof. It is undisputed that the order of dismissal of the respondent was made after an enquiry on the basis of a charge sheet submitted to him.
In the result, we hold that the order of the High Court remitting the matter back to the Labour Court was -not justified.

anchor.surface_text: These sections do not lend themselves to the construction that as soon as the Labour. Court, Tribunal etc. finds that there has been a violation of S. 33 it should award reinstatement. It must go through the proceedings which would have to be taken under S. 10 and it would be the duty of the Labour Court etc. to examine the merits of the case in the light of the principles formulated in the Indian Iron and Steel Co.s case.
In the result, we hold that the order of the High Court remitting the matter back to the Labour Court was -not justified.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in our view rightly refused to go into the question of the pendency of any conciliation proceeding but, even if there was any such proceeding, it would make no difference to the result in this case. The Tribunal would still have to consider whether the employers action was justified in the light of the decision in the Indian Iron Steel Co.s case.
In the result, we hold that the order of the High Court remitting the matter back to the Labour Court was -not justified.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal came to the conclusion that there was no justification for the respondents complaint to the police that the companys officials were in the habit of acting high-handedly and oppressively as alleged by him and further took the view that the respondents action in defaming two of the officers of the company could not but be pronounced as an act subversive of discipline...
In the result, we hold that the order of the High Court remitting the matter back to the Labour Court was -not justified.
